overview.title: What are Proper Nouns?
overview.description: Proper nouns are specific names of particular people, places, organizations, days, months, holidays, and brands. They always begin with a capital letter, no matter where they appear in a sentence.
key_points: Always capitalized - first letter must be uppercase
Refer to unique, specific entities (not general)
Include names of people, places, companies, dates
Different from common nouns which are general
overview.importance: Proper nouns help us identify specific individuals, locations, and entities. They're essential for clear communication and distinguishing between general and specific references.

sections.title: Types of Proper Nouns
sections.content: Proper nouns can be categorized into several main types, each serving a specific purpose in identifying unique entities.

subsections.subtitle: 1. Personal Names
subsections.text: Names of specific people, including first names, last names, and titles.

subsections.subtitle: 2. Geographical Names
subsections.text: Names of specific places, including cities, countries, continents, mountains, rivers, and oceans.

subsections.subtitle: 3. Organizations & Institutions
subsections.text: Names of specific companies, schools, organizations, and institutions.

subsections.subtitle: 4. Temporal Names
subsections.text: Names of specific days, months, holidays, and historical events.

subsections.subtitle: 5. Brand Names & Products
subsections.text: Names of specific brands, products, and commercial entities.

sections.title: Why Proper Nouns Matter
sections.content: Proper nouns serve several critical functions in communication.
points: Precision: They allow us to refer to specific entities without ambiguity
Identity: They help establish unique identities for people and places
Context: They provide cultural and geographical context
Formality: They add professionalism and accuracy to writing
Recognition: They make communication clearer and more specific

sections.title: When to Use Proper Nouns
sections.content: Understanding when to use proper nouns versus common nouns is essential.

scenarios.explanation: Use proper noun when you know the specific person's name

scenarios.common: I live in a big city.
scenarios.explanation: Use proper noun for the exact location name

scenarios.common: I work at a tech company.
scenarios.explanation: Use proper noun for the specific organization

grammar_rules.title: Always Capitalize the First Letter
grammar_rules.description: Every proper noun must begin with a capital letter, regardless of its position in the sentence.
correct_examples: I bought a new iPhone yesterday.
incorrect_examples: sarah loves traveling to paris. (Wrong: not capitalized)
The meeting is on monday. (Wrong: day not capitalized)
I bought a new iphone yesterday. (Wrong: brand not capitalized)
We celebrate christmas in december. (Wrong: holiday and month not capitalized)
grammar_rules.tip: Remember: Even if the proper noun appears in the middle or end of a sentence, it must always start with a capital letter.

grammar_rules.title: Don't Use Articles with Most Proper Nouns
grammar_rules.description: Most proper nouns don't need 'a', 'an', or 'the' before them, though there are exceptions.
correct_examples: We met Sarah at the park.
incorrect_examples: The John lives in the Paris. (Wrong: unnecessary 'the')
I visited the Egypt last year. (Wrong: country name doesn't need 'the')
She works at the Microsoft. (Wrong: company name doesn't need 'the')
grammar_rules.tip: Most single-word proper nouns don't need articles, but multi-word names and certain categories (rivers, mountain ranges) do.

grammar_rules.title: Capitalize All Important Words in Multi-Word Proper Nouns
grammar_rules.description: When a proper noun consists of multiple words, capitalize the first letter of each significant word.
incorrect_examples: United states of america (Wrong: 'states' should be capitalized)
New york Public library (Wrong: 'york' and 'library' need capitals)
World health organization (Wrong: 'health' and 'organization' need capitals)
grammar_rules.note: Small words like 'of', 'the', 'a', 'and' are usually lowercase unless they're the first word.
grammar_rules.tip: Capitalize nouns, adjectives, and verbs; lowercase articles, prepositions, and conjunctions (unless first word).

grammar_rules.title: Use Proper Nouns for Specific Time References
grammar_rules.description: Days of the week, months, and holidays are proper nouns and must be capitalized.
correct_examples: Independence Day is a national holiday.
incorrect_examples: The meeting is on monday. (Wrong: day not capitalized)
My birthday is in june. (Wrong: month not capitalized)
We celebrate christmas. (Wrong: holiday not capitalized)
grammar_rules.note: Seasons (spring, summer, fall, winter) are NOT capitalized unless part of a proper name.
grammar_rules.tip: Remember the acronym MDJH: Months, Days, Holidays - always capitalize!

grammar_rules.title: Don't Capitalize When Used as Common Nouns
grammar_rules.description: Some words can be both proper and common nouns. Only capitalize when referring to the specific entity.

examples.proper: I go to Harvard University. (specific institution)
examples.common: I go to university every day. (general concept)

examples.proper: President Biden spoke today. (specific person with title)
examples.common: The president of the company is here. (general position)

examples.proper: We visited the Grand Canyon. (specific place)
examples.common: We visited a beautiful canyon. (general place)

grammar_rules.tip: Ask yourself: 'Am I talking about THE specific one, or any one?' Specific = proper noun = capitalize.

examples.sentence: Dr. Smith is my dentist.
examples.analysis: 'Dr. Smith' is a proper noun (specific person's name and title)

examples.sentence: Queen Elizabeth ruled for many years.
examples.analysis: 'Queen Elizabeth' is a proper noun (specific monarch)

examples.sentence: I admire Nelson Mandela's courage.
examples.analysis: 'Nelson Mandela' is a proper noun (specific historical figure)

examples.analysis: 'Mrs. Johnson' is a proper noun (specific person)

examples.sentence: Shakespeare wrote many famous plays.
examples.analysis: 'Shakespeare' is a proper noun (specific author)

examples.sentence: Paris is known as the City of Light.
examples.analysis: 'Paris' is a proper noun (specific city)

examples.sentence: The Amazon River flows through South America.
examples.analysis: 'Amazon River' and 'South America' are proper nouns

examples.sentence: Mount Everest is the highest mountain.
examples.analysis: 'Mount Everest' is a proper noun (specific mountain)

examples.sentence: I visited the Statue of Liberty in New York.
examples.analysis: 'Statue of Liberty' and 'New York' are proper nouns

examples.sentence: The Pacific Ocean is vast and deep.
examples.analysis: 'Pacific Ocean' is a proper noun (specific ocean)

examples.sentence: I work at Google in California.
examples.analysis: 'Google' and 'California' are proper nouns

examples.sentence: Harvard University is very prestigious.
examples.analysis: 'Harvard University' is a proper noun (specific institution)

examples.sentence: The United Nations promotes peace.
examples.analysis: 'United Nations' is a proper noun (specific organization)

examples.sentence: I bought a new MacBook from Apple.
examples.analysis: 'MacBook' and 'Apple' are proper nouns (brand names)

examples.sentence: NASA launched a new spacecraft.
examples.analysis: 'NASA' is a proper noun (specific agency)

examples.sentence: Christmas is celebrated in December.
examples.analysis: 'Christmas' and 'December' are proper nouns

complex_sentences.sentence: Last Monday, Sarah and I visited the Louvre Museum in Paris, France.
complex_sentences.analysis: Five proper nouns: day (Monday), person (Sarah), place (Louvre Museum), city (Paris), country (France)

complex_sentences.sentence: Dr. Johnson works at Stanford University and teaches on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
complex_sentences.analysis: Four proper nouns: person with title, institution, and two days

complex_sentences.sentence: The Amazon River flows through Brazil, Peru, and Colombia in South America.
complex_sentences.analysis: Five proper nouns: river and four geographical locations

common_mistakes.wrong: I live in london and work at microsoft.
common_mistakes.correct: I live in London and work at Microsoft.
common_mistakes.explanation: City names and company names are proper nouns and must be capitalized.
common_mistakes.tip: Always check if a noun is a specific name - if yes, capitalize it!

common_mistakes.wrong: I met the Sarah at the Google office.
common_mistakes.correct: I met Sarah at the Google office.
common_mistakes.explanation: Personal names and most company names don't need 'the' before them.
common_mistakes.tip: Only use 'the' with proper nouns when it's part of the official name (The United States)

common_mistakes.wrong: The meeting is on monday in january.
common_mistakes.correct: The meeting is on Monday in January.
common_mistakes.explanation: Days of the week and months are always proper nouns and must be capitalized.
common_mistakes.tip: Think of days and months as names - they're always capitalized!

common_mistakes.wrong: I went to the Park with my Friend.
common_mistakes.correct: I went to the park with my friend.
common_mistakes.explanation: 'Park' and 'friend' are general (common) nouns here, not specific names.
common_mistakes.tip: Only capitalize if it's a specific name like 'Central Park' or 'Sarah' (friend's name)

common_mistakes.wrong: I visited the Empire state building.
common_mistakes.correct: I visited the Empire State Building.
common_mistakes.explanation: All significant words in multi-word proper nouns must be capitalized.
common_mistakes.tip: Capitalize each important word in the full name

common_mistakes.explanation: Seasons are common nouns and should not be capitalized unless starting a sentence.
common_mistakes.tip: Seasons ‚â† Months. Months = proper, Seasons = common

common_mistakes.wrong: I visited Sarahs house in New Yorks downtown.
common_mistakes.correct: I visited Sarah's house in New York's downtown.
common_mistakes.explanation: Use apostrophe + s to show possession with proper nouns.
common_mistakes.tip: Proper nouns follow the same possessive rules: add 's

common_mistakes.wrong: I want to be a President like president Lincoln.
common_mistakes.correct: I want to be a president like President Lincoln.
common_mistakes.explanation: General position = lowercase; specific person with title = capitalize.
common_mistakes.tip: If you can replace with 'a/an', it's common. If it's THE specific one, it's proper.

identification.title: Identify the Proper Nouns
identification.instructions: Find all the proper nouns in each sentence and explain why they're proper nouns.

questions.sentence: My friend John visited Paris last December.
The Titanic sank in the Atlantic Ocean in April 1912.
questions.explanation: Titanic (ship name), Atlantic Ocean (ocean name), April (month)

questions.sentence: Dr. Smith teaches at Harvard University on Mondays and Wednesdays.
We celebrate Thanksgiving in November with our family.
questions.explanation: Thanksgiving (holiday), November (month). 'Family' is common noun here.

questions.sentence: Apple Inc. released the iPhone in California on June 29, 2007.

correction.title: Fix the Capitalization Errors
correction.instructions: Correct the capitalization mistakes in these sentences.

questions.wrong: last monday, sarah visited the eiffel tower in paris.
questions.correct: Last Monday, Sarah visited the Eiffel Tower in Paris.
questions.explanation: Capitalize: Last (start of sentence), Monday (day), Sarah (person), Eiffel Tower (monument), Paris (city)

questions.wrong: i work at google and live near the golden gate bridge.
questions.correct: I work at Google and live near the Golden Gate Bridge.
questions.explanation: Capitalize: I (pronoun), Google (company), Golden Gate Bridge (monument)

questions.wrong: dr. johnson graduated from yale university in may.
questions.correct: Dr. Johnson graduated from Yale University in May.
questions.explanation: Capitalize: Dr. (title), Johnson (name), Yale University (institution), May (month)

questions.wrong: we celebrate christmas and easter in our Church.
questions.correct: We celebrate Christmas and Easter in our church.
questions.explanation: Capitalize: Christmas and Easter (holidays). Lowercase: church (not a specific church name)

questions.wrong: the united nations meets in new york city.
questions.correct: The United Nations meets in New York City.
questions.explanation: Capitalize: The (start), United Nations (organization), New York City (city)

writing_task.title: Write Your Own Sentences
writing_task.instructions: Write 5 sentences using at least 2 proper nouns in each sentence.
prompts: Write about your favorite place to visit
Describe someone you admire (use their name)
Talk about an important date or event
Mention a company or brand you like
Describe where you live or study
sample_answers: I visited the Louvre Museum in Paris with my friend Maria last July.
Steve Jobs founded Apple Inc. and created the iPhone.
Every Monday, I go to Stanford University for my classes.
Mount Everest is located in the Himalayas between Nepal and China.
My family celebrates Christmas and New Year's Eve together every December.

rubric.excellent: Uses 3+ proper nouns per sentence, all correctly capitalized
rubric.good: Uses 2 proper nouns per sentence, mostly correct capitalization
rubric.needs_improvement: Uses 1 proper noun per sentence or has capitalization errors

easy.question: Which word is a proper noun?
easy.explanation: 'Paris' is a proper noun (specific city name). Others are common nouns.

easy.question: Which is a proper noun?
easy.explanation: 'Monday' is a proper noun (specific day name), but needs capitalization.

easy.question: Choose the proper noun:
easy.explanation: 'Amazon' is a proper noun (specific name), others are common nouns.

easy.question: Which needs capitalization?
easy.explanation: 'Google' is a proper noun (company name) and must be capitalized.

medium.question: How many proper nouns: 'John visited Paris in December'?
medium.explanation: Three proper nouns: John (person), Paris (city), December (month).

medium.question: Which is correct?
medium.explanation: Personal names don't use articles. 'I met Sarah' is correct.

medium.question: Which is capitalized correctly?
medium.explanation: All significant words in multi-word proper nouns must be capitalized.

medium.question: Which is NOT a proper noun?
medium.explanation: 'Summer' is a season (common noun). Days, months, holidays are proper nouns.

medium.question: Choose the correct usage:
options: I go to University every day.
medium.explanation: Both can be correct depending on context: specific institution vs. general concept.

hard.question: Identify ALL proper nouns: 'Dr. Smith works at Stanford Hospital in California on Mondays.'
options: Dr. Smith, Stanford Hospital, California, Mondays
hard.explanation: Four proper nouns: Dr. Smith (person with title), Stanford Hospital (institution), California (state), Mondays (day).

hard.question: Which uses proper nouns correctly?
hard.explanation: When title and name are used together, both are capitalized, no 'the' needed.

hard.question: Which sentence has a capitalization error?
options: I visited the Grand Canyon last summer.
The Amazon River is very long.
We went to Central Park in New York.
She studies at the University Of California.
hard.explanation: 'Of' should not be capitalized in multi-word names (small prepositions stay lowercase).

hard.question: Which is the proper noun?
options: I visited the museum (specific but general)
I visited the Louvre Museum (specific name)
hard.explanation: Only 'the Louvre Museum' is a proper noun (specific name of a particular museum).

hard.question: How many errors: 'last Tuesday, sarah and i visited the eiffel tower in paris, france.'?
hard.explanation: 7 capitalization errors: Last, Tuesday, Sarah, I, Eiffel Tower (2 words), Paris, France.

fun_facts: The word 'proper' comes from Latin 'proprius' meaning 'one's own' - proper nouns are a thing's 'own' name!
There are over 6 million proper nouns in English (names of people, places, etc.)
Some proper nouns have become common nouns: 'xerox' (photocopy), 'kleenex' (tissue)
The longest proper noun is the full name of Bangkok: 'Krung Thep Maha Nakhon...' (168 letters!)
In some languages like German, ALL nouns are capitalized, not just proper nouns
'OK' is the most recognized proper noun worldwide (from 'Oll Korrect')
Brand names that become common words lose their capital letter (escalator, zipper, aspirin)
The most common proper noun in English is 'Jesus' followed by 'God'
Some proper nouns can be verbs too: 'I'll Google it' (Google as a verb)
Proper nouns make up about 15-20% of all nouns in typical English text
